title: Numerical investigation of the generalized Jang equation coupled to conformal flow of metrics
summary: A recent result of Jaracz has established nonexistence of global solutions to the coupled generalized Jang equation and zero divergence system which satisfy the asymptotic conditions needed to prove the Penrose conjecture by identifying a breakdown mechanism for the Jang slope at finite radius. In this work, we investigate whether a similar obstruction arises when the generalized Jang equation is instead coupled to the conformal flow of metrics. Restricting to spherical symmetry and time-symmetric initial data, we formulate a numerically tractable version of the Jang/conformal flow system. Our numerical results show no evidence of a finite radius breakdown analogous to that observed by Jaracz. Instead, the Jang slope remains regular and approaches its limiting value asymptotically. This behavior persists under controlled perturbations of the warping factor, indicating robustness of the observed phenomenon. These findings suggest that coupling to conformal flow of metrics alters the obstruction mechanism present in the Jang/zero divergence system, and hence that this system may still be viable for proving the Penrose conjecture.

AI.tldr: The paper investigates if the conformal flow system, when coupled with the generalized Jang equation, avoids the finite radius breakdown observed in previous studies, finding that the conformal flow system does not exhibit such a breakdown under spherical symmetry and time-symmetric data, making it a potential candidate for proving the Penrose conjecture.
AI.motivation: To determine if coupling the generalized Jang equation with the conformal flow of metrics circumvents the obstruction identified by Jaracz, which hindered proving the Penrose conjecture using the Jang/zero divergence system.
AI.method: The authors formulate a numerically tractable version of the Jang/conformal flow system under spherical symmetry and time-symmetric initial data. They perform numerical simulations and analyze the behavior of the Jang slope.
AI.result: Numerical results show the Jang slope remains regular and approaches its asymptotic limit without finite radius breakdown. This robustness persists under perturbations of the warping factor.
AI.conclusion: The conformal flow system may still be viable for proving the Penrose conjecture as it alters the obstruction mechanism present in the previous Jang/zero divergence system.

title: Compact Stars Sourced by Dark Matter Halos and Their Frozen States
summary: Inspired by regular black holes (RBHs) sourced by dark matter halos, we generalize the anisotropic energy-momentum tensor by relaxing the $P_r = -ρ$ condition between radial pressure and density. We demonstrate that while RBHs are a unique special case, a broader class of relations yields horizonless compact stars. Under specific parameter limits, these objects approach a ``frozen state," mimicking black hole features without an event horizon. These compact star solutions could satisfy weak energy conditions and provide a robust mechanism for dark matter-sourced black hole mimickers.

AI.tldr: The paper generalizes anisotropic energy-momentum tensors to explore dark matter-sourced horizonless compact stars, showing they can mimic black holes without violating energy conditions.
AI.motivation: To investigate whether relaxing the $P_r = -ρ$ condition allows for horizonless compact stars that act as black hole mimickers, addressing questions about dark matter's role in spacetime structures.
AI.method: Generalizing the anisotropic energy-momentum tensor beyond $P_r = -ρ$, deriving solutions, analyzing parameter limits leading to 'frozen states', and testing weak energy condition compliance.
AI.result: A broader class of relations besides RBHs can form horizonless compact stars; under specific parameters, these objects closely mimic black holes while meeting weak energy conditions.
AI.conclusion: Dark matter could create viable black hole mimickers that avoid event horizons, offering new avenues for astrophysical observations and tests of general relativity limits.

title: Gravitational equal-area law and critical phenomena of cuspy black hole shadow
summary: The formation of a cusp on a black hole shadow is a striking signature of physics beyond the Kerr paradigm. We demonstrate that this morphological change fundamentally alters the shadow's topology with the topological charge flipping from 1 to -1. To analyze this topological transition, we introduce a gravitational equal-area law, analogous to Maxwell's construction in thermodynamics, and identify a critical point for cusp formation. Near this point, we uncover universal behavior characterized by a critical exponent 1/2, which places this gravitational lensing system within the mean-field universality class. These results establish a new framework for testing fundamental physics of black hole shadows, reframing the search for deviations from general relativity as a targeted hunt for a distinct topological and critical phenomenon.

AI.tldr: The paper shows that a cusp forming on a black hole shadow changes its topology, flipping the topological charge from +1 to -1. A gravitational equal-area law and critical point with exponent 1/2 are introduced, suggesting a new method to test general relativity through observing such topological and critical phenomena.
AI.motivation: To explore signatures of physics beyond the Kerr metric and develop a framework for testing general relativity using black hole shadow observations.
AI.method: Analysis of shadow topology changes using a gravitational equal-area law analogous to Maxwell's construction, identification of critical points, and determination of universality class via critical exponent.
AI.result: Discovery of topological charge reversal, critical exponent 1/2 indicating mean-field universality class, and establishment of a framework linking cusp formation to deviations from Kerr.
AI.conclusion: Black hole shadow observations should focus on detecting topological transitions and critical phenomena to uncover physics beyond general relativity.

title: OmniSpectra: A Unified Foundation Model for Native Resolution Astronomical Spectra
summary: We present OmniSpectra, the first native-resolution foundation model for astronomy spectra. Unlike traditional models, which are limited to fixed-length input sizes or configurations, OmniSpectra handles spectra of any length at their original size, without resampling or interpolation. Despite the large-scale spectroscopic data from diverse surveys fueling the rapid growth of astronomy, existing foundation models are limited to a fixed wavelength range and specific instruments. OmniSpectra is the first foundation model to learn simultaneously from multiple real-world spectra surveys with different configurations at a large scale. We achieve this by designing a novel architecture with adaptive patching across variable lengths, sinusoidal global wavelength encoding, local positional embeddings through depthwise convolution, and validity-aware self-attention masks. Allowing us to learn multi-scale spatial patterns while skipping attention for invalid patches. Even with a limited training example, OmniSpectra demonstrates excellent zero-shot generalization compared to methods tailored for specific tasks. This transfer learning capability makes this model the state-of-the-art across various astronomy tasks, including source classification, redshift estimation, and properties prediction for stars and galaxies. OmniSpectra reduces the need for training individual models for different tasks from scratch, establishing itself as the next-generation astronomy foundation model.

AI.tldr: OmniSpectra is a versatile foundation model handling astronomy spectra of any length, using unique architecture components for adaptability and zero-shot generalization, achieving state-of-the-art performance across various tasks.
AI.motivation: Existing astronomy models are limited by fixed input sizes and configurations, making them unsuitable for diverse, large-scale spectral data from varying surveys. There was a need for a model that can process spectra at their native resolution without resampling.
AI.method: OmniSpectra employs adaptive patching for variable-length spectra, sinusoidal global wavelength encoding, local positional embeddings via depthwise convolutions, and validity-aware self-attention masks to efficiently learn multi-scale patterns and ignore invalid data patches.
AI.result: Even with limited training data, the model shows strong zero-shot generalization, outperforming task-specific models in classification, redshift estimation, and properties prediction, reducing the need for task-specific training.
AI.conclusion: This marks the next generation in astronomy foundation models, enabling efficient multi-task performance without per-task fine-tuning, thereby advancing spectral analysis across diverse astronomical studies.

title: Black hole based general relativistic limit of f(R) theory of gravity
summary: The Galactic Center black hole environment gives us new opportunity to test deviation from General Relativity and black hole physics. In this work we analytically generate the shape of the Galactic Center black hole by using a recently developed exact stationary, axisymmetric and vacuum solution of $f(R)$ gravity theory. By using scalaron mass as a free parameter we find that the shadow shape along with displacement and asymmetry is sensitive to the scalaron mass, even after keeping the black hole spin low. We recognize scalaron mass which is compatible with Kerr like quadrupole moment and hence black hole "no-hair" theorem. The same mass scale is found to reproduce the PPN parameter ($γ$) constrained in the weak field limit of the solar system. Gravitational identifiers, the Kretschmann scalar ($κ$) and gravitational potential ($φ$) have been used to infer scalaron masses in the regime of S-stars which are found to be consistent with the limits obtained using shadow scales. We ensure that $f(R)$ gravity scalaron has an appropriate general relativistic limit in the horizon scale of the black hole. We also identify the possibility of scale invariance of the General Relativistic limit.

AI.tldr: The paper explores deviations from General Relativity by studying the Galactic Center black hole's shadow using $f(R)$ gravity theory. The scalaron mass parameter influences the shadow's shape, displacement, and asymmetry, even with low spin. Results align with the Kerr quadrupole and solar system PPN constraints. Gravitational identifiers like Kretschmann scalar and potential also support the scalaron mass estimates. The analysis confirms a GR limit at the horizon scale, suggesting scale invariance possibilities.
AI.motivation: To test deviations from General Relativity and explore black hole physics using the unique environment of the Galactic Center. The study aims to investigate how $f(R)$ gravity predictions differ from standard GR, particularly in strong-field regimes and their observables like black hole shadows. It also seeks to verify consistency with existing constraints from PPN parameters and no-hair theorem.
AI.method: The authors analytically generate the black hole shape using an exact stationary axisymmetric vacuum solution of $f(R)$ gravity. They vary the scalaron mass as a free parameter to study its effect on shadow properties. They cross-validate results using gravitational identifiers (Kretschmann scalar, potential) and ensure consistency with Kerr quadrupole moment and solar system PPN constraints.
AI.result: Scalaron mass significantly affects the shadow's shape and asymmetry even at low spin. The derived mass scale aligns with solar system PPN $γ$ constraints and Kerr-like quadrupole, upholding the no-hair theorem. Kretschmann scalar and gravitational potential analyses of S-star regimes confirm scalaron mass limits matching shadow-based results. General Relativistic limits are preserved at the horizon scale, suggesting scale invariance possibilities.
AI.conclusion: The $f(R)$ gravity model provides a testable framework for probing GR deviations through black hole shadow observations. Scalaron mass acts as a key parameter linking strong-field phenomena to solar system constraints. The consistency across shadow, PPN, and no-hair theorem tests supports this model's viability. Future observations of the Galactic Center black hole could further constrain $f(R)$ gravity parameters and explore general relativistic limits' behavior.

title: LISA and the LISA Science Team
comment: 8 pages, written on behalf of the LISA Science Team and presented at Mathematical Methods for the General Relativistic Two-body Problem at NUS, Sinagpore
summary: LISA, the Laser Interferometer Space Antenna, due to launch mid-2035, is a large class space mission by the European Space Agency (ESA). In partnership with NASA and ESA-member states, ESA is on track to launch what is expected to be the first space-based gravitational wave detector. By hosting detectors in space, one gains access to a lower frequency band of gravitational wave sources and with them, a plethora of new science. To maximise this scientific gain, ESA and NASA selected 20 scientists for the LISA Science Team, to carry out and/or lead necessary actions on the run up to LISA launch. We give a short overview and update of the LISA mission, some of its science objectives and related waveforms, as well as the work of the LISA Science Team as of December 2025.

AI.tldr: The LISA mission, a collaboration between ESA, NASA, and ESA member states, aims to launch a space-based gravitational wave detector in mid-2035. This mission will access lower frequency gravitational wave sources, enabling new scientific discoveries. A team of 20 scientists was selected to prepare for the mission, and this paper provides an overview of the mission, its objectives, related waveforms, and the Science Team's progress as of December 2025.
AI.motivation: To leverage space-based detection for accessing lower frequency gravitational waves, which are inaccessible to ground-based detectors like LIGO, thereby expanding scientific exploration and understanding of astrophysical phenomena.
AI.method: The paper provides an overview of the LISA mission, its technical specifications, scientific objectives, and the roles of the LISA Science Team in preparing for the mission's launch. It discusses planned observations and associated waveform models for gravitational wave sources.
AI.result: An updated mission status, key science objectives, and the ongoing preparatory work by the Science Team are outlined, highlighting LISA's potential to observe a variety of gravitational wave sources in lower frequency bands.
AI.conclusion: LISA's launch in mid-2035 will open a new observational window in gravitational wave astronomy. The Science Team's efforts are crucial for ensuring mission success and maximizing scientific returns through coordinated preparation and analysis.

title: Branching Ratios of $H_{1,2,3} \rightarrow μ^{+}μ^{-}$ in the Broken-Phase N2HDM
comment: 11 pages, presented at Annual Workshop 2026 on High Energy Physics. Theoretical and Experimental Challenges (HEP-TEC-2026)
summary: Recent evidence from the ATLAS Collaboration for the rare decay $H \rightarrow μ^{+}μ^{-}$ provides a unique window into the Higgs boson's coupling to second-generation fermions. In this work, we investigate how this signal can probe physics beyond the Standard Model by computing the branching ratios $B(H_{i} \rightarrow μ^{+}μ^{-})$ for the three CP-even Higgs bosons $H_{1,2,3}$ in the broken-phase Next-to-Two-Higgs-Doublet Model (N2HDM). We incorporate one-loop radiative corrections and analyze deviations from the Standard Model prediction due to modified Yukawa couplings, scalar mixing, and singlet--doublet interactions. By confronting our results with the ATLAS signal strength $μ= 1.4 \pm 0.4$, we identify viable regions of the N2HDM parameter space, characterized by tan$β$, the singlet vacuum expectation value, and scalar masses, and assess the model's capacity to explain potential enhancements in the dimuon channel. Our study demonstrates that precision measurements of $H \rightarrow μ^{+}μ^{-}$ serve as a powerful tool to test extended Higgs sectors and uncover new physics at current and future colliders.

AI.tldr: The paper examines the rare Higgs boson decay H→μ⁺μ⁻ in the N2HDM framework, using ATLAS data to probe beyond the Standard Model by analyzing branching ratios, radiative corrections, and parameter space regions.
AI.motivation: To explore physics beyond the Standard Model using the ATLAS Collaboration's H→μ⁺μ⁻ data, focusing on second-generation fermion couplings and testing the N2HDM predictions.
AI.method: Computed branching ratios for three CP-even Higgs bosons in N2HDM with one-loop corrections, considering Yukawa couplings, scalar mixing, and singlet-doublet interactions. Compared results with ATLAS signal strength μ=1.4±0.4.
AI.result: Identified viable N2HDM parameter regions (tanβ, singlet vacuum expectation value, scalar masses) that explain the observed μ enhancement, showing the model's potential to extend Higgs sector understanding.
AI.conclusion: Precision measurements of H→μ⁺μ⁻ decay can effectively test extended Higgs sectors and reveal new physics at current/future colliders like the LHC.

title: Dynamic shocks powered by a wide, relativistic, super-Eddington outflow launched by an accreting neutron star in the mid-20th century
summary: Accreting systems can launch powerful outflows which interact with the surrounding medium. We combine new radio observations of the accreting neutron star X-ray binary (XRB) Circinus X-1 (Cir X-1) with archival radio observations going back 24 years. The $\sim3$ pc scale wide-angle radio and X-ray emitting caps found around Cir X-1 are identified as synchrotron emitting shocks with significant proper motion and morphological evolution on decade timescales. Proper motion measurements of the shocks reveal they are mildly relativistic and decelerating, with apparent velocity of $0.14c\pm0.03c$ at a propagation distance of 2 pc. We demonstrate that these shocks are likely powered by a hidden relativistic ($\gtrsim0.3c$) wide-angle conical outflow launched in $1972\pm3$, in stark contrast to known structures around other XRBs formed by collimated jets over 1000s of years. The minimum time-averaged power of the outflow required to produce the observed synchrotron emission is $\sim0.1L_\text{Edd}$, while the time-averaged power required for the kinetic energy of the shocks is $\sim40 \left(\frac{n}{10^{-2} \text{cm}^{-3}}\right)L_\text{Edd}$, where $n$ is the average ambient medium number density. This reveals the outflow powering the shocks is likely significantly super-Eddington. We measure significant linear polarisation up to $52\pm6\%$ in the shocks demonstrating the presence of an ordered magnetic field of strength $\sim200~μ\text{G}$. We show that the shocks are potential PeVatrons, capable of accelerating electrons to $\sim0.7~\text{PeV}$ and protons to $\sim20~\text{PeV}$, and we estimate the injection and energetic efficiencies of electron acceleration in the shocks. Finally, we predict that next generation gamma-ray facilities may be able to detect hadronic signatures from the shocks.

AI.tldr: The paper analyzes 24 years of radio observations of the accreting neutron star X-ray binary Circinus X-1, revealing powerful wide-angle outflows producing shock structures that decelerate to ~0.14c. These shocks, with strong polarization and potential for accelerating particles to PeV energies, suggest a super-Eddington outflow and may explain high-energy astrophysical phenomena
AI.motivation: To understand the origin and evolution of shocks in accreting neutron star systems and their role in accelerating particles to ultra-high energies, contrasting with typical collimated jet structures observed in other XRBs.
AI.method: Combination of new and archival radio/X-ray data over 24 years to measure proper motion, morphology, and polarization of shocks around Cir X-1. Calculations of outflow power requirements compared to Eddington luminosity and ambient density modeling.
AI.result: Shocks show decelerated relativistic motion (~0.14c), powered by a 1972-era ~0.3c outflow. High polarization indicates organized magnetic fields. The outflow's kinetic power implies super-Eddington conditions, with potential to accelerate particles to PeV energies.
AI.conclusion: Cir X-1's outflow dynamics differ significantly from classical XRBs, suggesting transient energetic events can produce ultra-relativistic shocks capable of PeV particle acceleration. This has implications for understanding cosmic accelerators and future gamma-ray observations.

title: Weyl-transverse gravity with boundaries
summary: We develop the covariant phase space formulation of Weyl-transverse gravity (WTG) in the presence of general timelike and spacelike boundaries. WTG is classically equivalent to General Relativity (GR) but possesses a reduced gauge symmetry consisting of Weyl transformations and transverse diffeomorphisms, together with a fixed background volume form. This structure modifies the variational principle and the definition of conserved quantities relative to GR. We derive the symplectic potential, presymplectic current, and Hamiltonian generators associated with transverse diffeomorphisms, and we identify a set of boundary conditions under which the WTG action is differentiable. These include Dirichlet and Neumann conditions for both the auxiliary Weyl-invariant metric and the dynamical metric, as well as a natural implementation of York boundary conditions, for which WTG exhibits a particularly transparent geometric formulation. We obtain the Noether current and surface charge, clarify the role of the Lagrangian ambiguity related to the cosmological constant, and evaluate the Hamiltonian identity on spacetimes containing a bifurcate Killing horizon. The resulting first-law relation shows that variations of the cosmological constant can contribute nontrivially unless additional physical restrictions are imposed.

AI.tldr: The paper develops the covariant phase space formulation for Weyl-transverse gravity (WTG) with general timelike and spacelike boundaries. It explores how WTG's reduced gauge symmetry modifies conserved quantities and variational principles compared to General Relativity. The study includes boundary conditions, Noether currents, and a first-law relation involving the cosmological constant.
AI.motivation: To address the need for a covariant phase space formalism in WTG, which maintains classical equivalence to GR but with a distinct gauge structure. This allows for clearer definitions of conserved quantities and variational principles, especially at boundaries where standard GR approaches may face ambiguities.
AI.method: Derived symplectic structures (potential/current), Hamiltonian generators, and boundary conditions (Dirichlet, Neumann, York) for WTG. Analyzed Noether currents, surface charges, and the impact of Lagrangian ambiguities related to the cosmological constant. Evaluated the Hamiltonian identity near Killing horizons.
AI.result: Identified boundary conditions for differentiable WTG action, clarified the role of cosmological constant ambiguities, and derived a first law where cosmological constant variations contribute unless restricted. Surface charges and Hamiltonian generators were explicitly determined.
AI.conclusion: WTG's formalism provides a geometrically transparent framework for GR-equivalent dynamics, highlighting the necessity of boundary condition choices and constraints on cosmological variations for physically consistent results.

title: Non-uniform Antenna Loading Effect on Embedded Element Patterns and Application to Fault Detection
comment: 6 pages, 5 pages, to be submitted to IEEE-TAP as Communication
summary: A new, iterative algorithm is presented to calculate the Embedded Element Pattern (EEP) tranformation from a set of patterns computed for a uniform antenna port loading (scaled identinty matrix) to a set of those computed for a non-uniform one (arbitrary diagonal matrix). This method proves particularly useful when inverting the computations to derive the non-uniform entries of the arbitrary load, given the minimum number of EEPs necessary, which disposes of the redundancy of other matrix-based computations and leads to numerically stable impedance fault calculation. As the EEPs are envisioned to be obtained primarily through measurement, our method is also tested with the inclusion of various noise components and its convergence is evaluated, suggesting the minimum SNR and fading level of the measurement apparatus, as well as the optimal choice of reference antenna to minimise the estimation error.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces an iterative algorithm to compute Embedded Element Patterns (EEPs) for non-uniform antenna loads from uniform ones, improving efficiency and numerical stability while handling measurement noise.
AI.motivation: To address the computational redundancy and numerical instability in existing matrix-based methods for deriving non-uniform antenna loads from EEPs, and to handle real-world measurement noise.
AI.method: An iterative algorithm transforms EEPs from uniform (scaled identity matrix) to non-uniform (arbitrary diagonal matrix) loads, minimizing required EEPs and tested with noise to evaluate convergence and measurement requirements.
AI.result: The method eliminates redundancy, achieves numerical stability in impedance fault calculations, and determines minimal SNR, fading levels, and optimal reference antennas for accurate measurements.
AI.conclusion: The proposed algorithm effectively computes non-uniform loads with fewer EEPs, robust to noise, providing guidelines for practical measurement setups in antenna diagnostics.

title: Single-wave solutions of the neutrino fast flavor system. Part I. Mechanical properties
summary: A dense neutrino plasma can exhibit collective flavor evolution caused by neutrino--neutrino refraction. Recently, a new class of exact nonlinear inhomogeneous solutions was discovered: single-wave (SW) solutions of the fast flavor system. The key property is that the flavor occupation numbers remain homogeneous, whereas the field of flavor coherence varies spatially with a single wave vector. The equations of motion for this structure resemble those of a collection of classical spins, in analogy with the homogeneous slow and fast flavor cases. In contrast, the SW system is not integrable (it does not possess Gaudin invariants) so that, while two-beam pendulum solutions are inevitable, they do not extend to a multi-angle system. We develop a taxonomy of all known nonlinear collective flavor solutions, explaining the overlap between categories and their differences.

AI.tldr: The paper explores new exact nonlinear inhomogeneous solutions (single-wave solutions) in dense neutrino plasmas, where flavor occupation numbers stay homogeneous while flavor coherence varies spatially. These solutions, analogous to classical spins but lacking integrability, highlight limitations in extending two-beam pendulum models to multi-angle systems.
AI.motivation: To classify and understand nonlinear collective flavor evolution in dense neutrino plasmas, addressing gaps in previous homogeneous models and integrability constraints.
AI.method: Deriving equations of motion for single-wave solutions, comparing their properties (e.g., non-integrability) to prior cases (slow/fast flavor systems), and categorizing all known solutions.
AI.result: Identified SW solutions' unique characteristics (homogeneous occupation numbers, single-wave coherence variation) and demonstrated that they do not support Gaudin invariants, restricting their applicability in multi-angle systems.
AI.conclusion: The taxonomy clarifies distinctions between solution classes, emphasizing that non-integrable SW solutions require different treatment from integrable systems and cannot trivially extend two-beam models to more complex scenarios.

title: Spin-down changes in PSR B0540-69 induced by a drift of the magnetic axis
summary: The dynamics of the solid crust + magnetic field lines of pulsars is a much debated issue, and remains unsettled after 50 years. Some pieces of evidence have emerged to complete and confirm theoretical calculations and expectations. We discuss in the present work an interpretation of the behavior of the ''Crab Twin'' pulsar PSR B0540-69 in terms of the evolution of the magnetic field/quakes, connecting the behavior of the braking index with the underlying platelet drift and sudden discontinuous rearrangement (fast-slip) and long-term ones (slow-slip events), suggested by analogy with existing theoretical picture observed in the Earth's crust. The relationship of this scenario with permanent torque-changing glitches seen in the Crab and other young pulsars, and a set of similar events in the same object and others is addressed. We conclude that this physical approach is in principle consistent with all these sudden events, and point out future work to clarify the whole picture.

AI.tldr: The paper investigates the dynamics of the Crab Twin pulsar PSR B0540-69's magnetic field and crustal quakes, linking its braking index changes to both fast and slow-slip events analogous to Earth's crustal behaviors. It suggests this model aligns with observed glitches in pulsars and proposes further research.
AI.motivation: To resolve long-standing debates about pulsar crust-magnetic field dynamics by analyzing PSR B0540-69's behavior, integrating recent evidence with existing theoretical models.
AI.method: Interprets the pulsar's braking index variations through a model combining platelet drift and sudden magnetic rearrangements (fast-slip) with slower processes (slow-slip events), drawing parallels to Earth's tectonics. Examines connections to torque glitches in Crab-like pulsars.
AI.result: The proposed scenario is consistent with observed sudden events in pulsars, explaining glitch phenomena through crustal and magnetic field interactions. Identifies gaps requiring further study.
AI.conclusion: This physical framework provides a coherent explanation for pulsar quakes and glitches. Future work is needed to fully validate the model and understand underlying mechanisms.

title: Nonlinear tails of massive scalar fields around a black hole
summary: Nonlinear effects play a fundamental role in the late-time ringdown of black holes, with direct implications for gravitational-wave observations. For massive fields, these dynamics become richer, yet their nonlinear signatures remain poorly understood. Here, we systematically study nonlinear tails of massive scalar perturbations, from a toy model with ingoing and outgoing sources to a self-interacting scalar model, revealing nonlinear tails and contrasting the results with their linear counterparts. We find that the nonlinear tails of massive scalar fields, opposite to massless ones, decay as the same rate as linear tails in the intermediate time, independent of source parameters or initial conditions. Nevertheless, quadratic quasinormal modes could serve as a probe to the nonlinear effects of massive fields.

AI.tldr: The study investigates the nonlinear ringdown effects of massive scalar fields on black holes, showing that their decay rates match linear predictions in the intermediate phase, unlike massless fields, with quadratic quasinormal modes offering a potential probe for nonlinear dynamics.
AI.motivation: To understand nonlinear signatures in the late-time ringdown of black holes, particularly for massive fields where such effects are less explored despite their importance for gravitational-wave observations.
AI.method: Systematically analyzes nonlinear tails using a toy model with ingoing/outgoing sources and a self-interacting scalar model, comparing results with linear counterparts.
AI.result: Nonlinear tails of massive scalar fields decay at the same rate as linear tails in the intermediate time, independent of source parameters/initial conditions, contrasting with massless fields. Quadratic quasinormal modes can probe nonlinear effects.
AI.conclusion: Nonlinear dynamics of massive scalar fields differ fundamentally from massless ones, with quasinormal mode analysis providing a viable method to detect these effects in gravitational-wave data.

title: Distance-Independent Atmospheric Refraction Correction for Accurate Retrieval of Fireball Trajectories
comment: Accepted for publication in Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society
summary: Accurate determination of fireball direction is essential for retrieving trajectories and velocities. Errors in these measurements have significant implications, affecting the calculated pre-impact orbit, influencing mass estimates, and impacting the accuracy of dark flight simulations, where applicable. Here we implement a new atmospheric refraction correction technique that addresses a significant aspect previously overlooked in the field of meteor science. Traditional refraction correction techniques, originally designed for objects positioned at infinite distances, tend to overcompensate when applied to objects within the Earth's atmosphere. To rectify this issue, our study introduces the concept of the atmospheric refraction delta z correction technique, involving the artificial elevation of the observer site height above sea level. We utilize analytically derived formulas for the delta z correction in conjunction with commonly used refraction models, validating these results against a numerical solution that traces light rays through the atmosphere. This ray-tracing model is applied to finely meshed atmospheric layers, yielding precise correction values. We evaluate multiple sources of error in order to quantify the achievable accuracy of the proposed method. Our approach (1) enables the determination of fireball positions with improved astrometric accuracy, (2) removes the explicit dependence on the fireball distance from the observer or its height above Earth's surface within the limits imposed by realistic atmospheric variability, and (3) simplifies meteor data processing by providing a robust framework for analyzing low-elevation fireball observations, for which atmospheric refraction is significant and is automatically corrected by the method. As a result of this work, we provide open, publicly accessible software for calculating the delta z correction.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a new atmospheric refraction correction technique, called delta z, to improve the accuracy of fireball direction measurements by adjusting observer site height. This method enhances astrometric accuracy, simplifies data processing, and accounts for atmospheric variability without needing fireball distance or height.
AI.motivation: Traditional refraction correction methods overcompensate for atmospheric effects on nearby objects, leading to errors in trajectory, velocity, pre-impact orbit, mass estimates, and dark flight simulations.
AI.method: The delta z correction elevates the observer's height artificially in refraction models and combines analytic formulas with ray-tracing through atmospheric layers, validated against numerical solutions.
AI.result: Achieved higher astrometric accuracy, eliminated dependence on fireball distance/height, and provided an open-source tool for applying the correction.
AI.conclusion: The new method improves meteor data analysis, especially for low-elevation events, and its software enables consistent, automated refraction corrections across the field.

title: Exploring Quantumness at Long-Baseline Neutrino Experiments
summary: Violations of classicality can be probed through measurements performed on a system at different times, as proposed by Leggett and Garg. Specifically, violations of Leggett-Garg inequalities suggest the presence of quantum effects in macroscopic systems. Long-baseline neutrino experiments provide some of the longest available propagation distances over which such tests can be performed. Previous studies of Leggett-Garg tests in the neutrino sector have largely focused on showing that the oscillation probabilities can violate classical bounds for certain parameter choices. In this work, we develop a more complete and data-driven framework that treats both the distributions representing the classical and quantum behavior, as well as the experimental uncertainties. We consider MINOS, T2K, NOvA, as well as the upcoming DUNE, and present the respective statistical significance for distinguishing quantum behavior from classical scenarios at these long-baseline neutrino experiments. Among them, we find that T2K yields the most significant violation of classicality, at the level of $\sim 14 σ$, with NOvA and projections for DUNE also resulting in a significance of more than $5σ$.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a data-driven framework to analyze Leggett-Garg inequalities in neutrino experiments, finding T2K achieves ~14σ significance in violating classicality, with NOvA and DUNE also exceeding 5σ.
AI.motivation: To rigorously test quantum vs. classical behavior in macroscopic systems using neutrino oscillation data, addressing limitations of prior studies that only showed violations for specific parameters.
AI.method: Developed a framework analyzing classical and quantum probability distributions alongside experimental uncertainties, applying it to MINOS, T2K, NOvA, and DUNE datasets.
AI.result: T2K shows the strongest violation (~14σ), while NOvA and projected DUNE results also surpass 5σ significance, demonstrating clear quantum behavior over classical scenarios.
AI.conclusion: Long-baseline neutrino experiments provide robust evidence against classicality, with the framework establishing a new standard for such quantum tests in macroscopic systems.

title: The long quest for vacuum birefringence in magnetars: 1E 1547.0-5408 and the elusive smoking gun
summary: Magnetars are now known to be among the most strongly polarized celestial sources in X-rays. Here we report on the $500\,\mathrm{ks}$ observation of the magnetar 1E 1547.0-5408 performed by the Imaging X-ray Polarimetry Explorer (IXPE) in March 2025. The IXPE spectrum is well reproduced by a single thermal component with blackbody temperature $kT_\mathrm{BB}\sim 0.67\,\mathrm{keV}$ and emission radius $R_\mathrm{BB}\sim 1.2\,\mathrm{km}$. The source exhibits a high linear polarization degree in the $2$--$6\,\mathrm{keV}$ band ($\mathrm{PD}=47.7\pm2.9\%$) with polarization angle $\mathrm{PA}=75^\circ.8 \pm 1.^\circ8$, measured West of celestial North. While $\mathrm{PA}$ does not appear to vary with energy, there is some evidence (at the $1σ$ confidence level) of a minimum in $\mathrm{PD}$ between $3$ and $4\,\mathrm{keV}$, compatible with what is expected by partial mode conversion at the vacuum resonance in a magnetized atmosphere. Phase-resolved spectral and polarimetric analyses reveal that X-ray thermal radiation likely originates from a single, fairly small hot spot with a non-uniform temperature distribution. Fitting the phase-dependent $\mathrm{PA}$ measured by IXPE with a rotating vector model (RVM) constrains the source geometry and indicates that both the dipole axis and line-of-sight are misaligned with respect to the spin axis. Under these conditions, the high polarization of the source cannot be regarded as compelling evidence for the presence of vacuum birefringence in the star magnetosphere. Nevertheless, the fact that the RVM successfully reproduces the modulation of the X-ray polarization angle and the behavior of $\mathrm{PD}$ with the energy hint once more to the presence of QED effects in magnetars.

AI.tldr: IXPE observations of magnetar 1E 1547.0-5408 reveal high X-ray polarization with a thermal spectrum from a small hot spot. Polarization angle stability and energy-dependent PD variations suggest QED effects like vacuum resonance mode conversion, though vacuum birefringence isn't conclusively confirmed.
AI.motivation: To investigate the origin of high X-ray polarization in magnetars and test predictions involving QED effects like vacuum birefringence through detailed spectral and polarimetric analysis.
AI.method: 500 ks IXPE observation analyzed using phase-resolved spectroscopy/polarimetry. Fitted with thermal models, applied rotating vector model (RVM) to constrain geometry. Studied polarization degree (PD) and angle (PA) variations with energy and phase.
AI.result: High PD (47.7%) at 2-6 keV with stable PA (~75.8°). Slight PD dip at 3-4 keV suggests partial mode conversion. RVM analysis shows misalignment between dipole/spin axes and line-of-sight. Thermal emission来自 small hotspot with non-uniform temp.
AI.conclusion: While vacuum birefringence isn't confirmed, observed PD/PA behavior aligns with QED effects in magnetar magnetospheres. Results highlight RVM's utility and emphasize need for further QED studies in extreme magnetic fields.

title: Exact Kerr-Newman-(A)dS and other spacetimes in bumblebee gravity: employing a novel generating technique
comment: 40 pages, 5 figure; Supplementary Wolfram Mathematica file with derivations added to the source archive
summary: In this work, we show that if the bumblebee field in the Einstein-bumblebee theory is given by its vacuum expectation value ($B_μ=b_μ$) and it is not dynamical ($\partial_μB_ν-\partial_νB_μ=0$), then these conditions uniquely provide a generating technique, allowing us to construct exact solutions to bumblebee gravity from the vacuum solutions by adding a term $\sim b_μb_ν$ to the metric tensor. Also, we show that the bumblebee field within this technique is proportional to the tangential vector of the (timelike or spacelike) geodesic curve in the background vacuum spacetime, and can be easily found knowing the solution to the Hamilton-Jacobi equation. Moreover, we prove that this technique can be extended to the case of any non-zero cosmological constant and the presence of the electromagnetic field. We apply this generating technique and obtain the bumblebee extension of the Kerr-Newman-Taub-NUT-(anti-)de Sitter spacetime. We show that this extension is not unique, as it depends on the exact geodesic curve one chooses to associate a bumblebee field with. Then, by considering various special cases of this generic solution, we demonstrate that the condition of the global reality of the bumblebee field limits the set of geodesics with which we can associate it.

AI.tldr: The paper presents a method to construct exact solutions in bumblebee gravity by modifying the metric tensor with a b_μb_ν term, extending to cosmological constants and electromagnetic fields, resulting in non-unique bumblebee extensions of specific spacetimes.
AI.motivation: To explore exact solutions in Einstein-bumblebee theory by fixing the bumblebee field's vacuum expectation value and removing its dynamics, leading to a generating technique for spacetime solutions.
AI.method: By setting the bumblebee field to its vacuum expectation value and imposing non-dynamical conditions, the authors derive a method to construct solutions from vacuum spacetimes by adding a b_μb_ν term. The bumblebee field is linked to geodesic tangents via the Hamilton-Jacobi equation solutions. The technique accommodates non-zero cosmological constants and electromagnetic fields.
AI.result: A generating technique is established, successfully applied to create a bumblebee extension of the Kerr-Newman-Taub-NUT-(A)dS spacetime. The resulting solutions depend on chosen geodesic curves, and the global reality condition restricts valid geodesics for the bumblebee field.
AI.conclusion: The approach provides a systematic way to generate exact solutions in bumblebee gravity, highlighting non-uniqueness based on geodesic selection and constraints imposed by the bumblebee field's reality.

title: Radio-Interferometric Image Reconstruction with Denoising Diffusion Restoration Models
summary: Reconstructing images of the radio sky from incomplete Fourier information is a key challenge in radio astronomy. In this work, we present a method for radio interferometeic image reconstruction using a data-driven prior for the radio sky based on denoising diffusion probabilistic models (DDPMs). We first train a DDPM on radio galaxy observations from the VLA FIRST survey. We create simulated VLA, EHT, and ALMA observations of radio galaxies, then use an unsupervised posterior sampling method called Denoising Diffusion Restoration Models (DDRM) to reconstruct the corresponding images, using our DDPM as a prior. Our approach is agnostic to the measured radio interferometric data and naturally incorporates the physics of the measurement process. We are able to reconstruct images with very high fidelity PSNR>60, a marked improvement over CLEAN and similar image reconstruction methods using conditional DDPMs

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a method using denoising diffusion probabilistic models (DDPMs) to reconstruct high-fidelity radio sky images from incomplete interferometric data, achieving PSNR>60 and outperforming traditional methods like CLEAN.
AI.motivation: Addressing the challenge of reconstructing radio sky images from incomplete Fourier data obtained via radio interferometry.
AI.method: Training a DDPM on VLA FIRST survey data, then applying Denoising Diffusion Restoration Models (DDRM) with the DDPM prior to simulate and reconstruct images from VLA, EHT, and ALMA observations.
AI.result: Achieved PSNR>60 in image reconstructions, significantly better than traditional CLEAN and conditional DDPM-based methods.
AI.conclusion: The proposed method effectively leverages data-driven priors and physical measurement models to produce high-fidelity reconstructions across diverse radio telescopes.

title: Structure functions for the inclusive semileptonic $b$-quark decay at NNLO: a semi-analytic calculation
summary: We present a study of the inclusive charmless semileptonic $b$ decay, $b\to X_u\ell\barν$ at next-to-next-to-leading order (NNLO) in perturbative QCD, with the primary aim of extracting the hadronic structure functions $W_i$ at NNLO. The analysis is based on a numerical calculation of the relevant kinematic distributions using a phase-space slicing method to handle infrared-sensitive contributions from real gluon emissions. We use known results from Heavy Quark Effective Theory and Soft-Collinear Effective Theory to extract the singular terms and construct a model for the regular contributions to the structure functions at NNLO, then perform a fit to the numerical results. We use our approximate structure functions to compute various kinematic distributions and moments: the comparison with existing analytic and numerical results shows very good agreement, which is further improved including the available analytic results in the fit.

AI.tldr: The paper presents a NNLO analysis of the charmless semileptonic $b$ decay $b	o X_u ell arν$ using phase-space slicing and effective field theories to extract structure functions, achieving good agreement with existing results.
AI.motivation: To accurately determine hadronic structure functions $W_i$ at NNLO by improving precision in perturbative QCD calculations for $b\rightarrow X_u ell arν$ decays, which are critical for understanding CKM matrix elements and testing the Standard Model.
AI.method: Used phase-space slicing to handle real gluon emissions' infrared sensitivity, combined Heavy Quark Effective Theory (HQET) and Soft-Collinear Effective Theory (SCET) results to extract singular terms. Constructed model for regular contributions, performed fits to numerical results, and computed kinematic distributions/moments.
AI.result: Achieved very good agreement between the approximate structure functions and existing analytic/numerical results, with further improvement when incorporating known analytic results into the fit.
AI.conclusion: The methodology successfully constructs accurate NNLO structure functions for $b\rightarrow X_u ell arν$ decays, enhancing precision in extracting CKM parameters and validating effective theory approaches with phase-space slicing techniques.

title: Source identification for the Swift-BAT 150-month hard X-ray catalog using soft X-ray observations
summary: We present a comprehensive catalog of 251 potential counterparts for 250 unassociated hard X-ray sources detected in the Swift Burst Alert Telescope (BAT) 150-month hard X-ray survey. Over 150 months of observation, BAT has detected 2339 sources in the 15-150 keV energy range. Among these, 344 do not have a previously identified low-energy counterpart. Our study focuses on the analysis of soft X-ray observations at energies below 10 keV, spatially overlapping with these new Swift-BAT hard X-ray sources. Such observations were taken with Chandra, Swift-XRT, eROSITA, and XMM-Newton. Within the sample of 251 potential counterparts, 94 (37 percent) are identified as active galactic nuclei and 58 (23 percent) as galaxies. The remaining 99 sources (40 percent) include pulsars, cataclysmic variables, and unclassified soft X-ray counterparts in the 0.5-10 keV band. Redshift information is available for 139 out of the 251 sources, and its distribution is in close agreement with the redshift distribution of previous BAT catalogs. We also present the results of a small optical spectroscopy campaign of 9 out of 58 galaxies. The majority of these are classified as Seyfert 2 galaxies at redshifts slightly larger than the median of the BAT AGN sample.

AI.tldr: This study analyzes potential soft X-ray counterparts for 250 unassociated hard X-ray sources detected by Swift-BAT, identifying 251 candidates primarily as AGN, galaxies, and other sources, with redshift data and optical spectroscopy supporting their classifications.
AI.motivation: To identify and classify previously unassociated hard X-ray sources from the Swift-BAT survey using multi-wavelength observations, enhancing catalog completeness and understanding of high-energy source populations.
AI.method: Combined soft X-ray data from Chandra, Swift-XRT, eROSITA, XMM-Newton to cross-match with Swift-BAT sources, followed by redshift analysis and optical spectroscopy for selected galaxies.
AI.result: 251 counterparts identified: 94 AGN (37%), 58 galaxies (23%), and others (40%). Redshifts aligned with previous BAT catalogs; 9 galaxies classified as Seyfert 2 with slightly higher redshifts.
AI.conclusion: Multi-wavelength observations effectively characterize unknown high-energy sources, improving sky mapping and highlighting the prevalence of AGN in unassociated hard X-ray populations.

title: Roche limit and stellar disruption in the Simpson--Visser spacetime
summary: Due to the tidal forces that a black hole can produce, certain types of compact objects may undergo disruption as they approach the black hole. This disruption point is known as the Roche limit (or Roche radius). In this work, we studied the tidal forces arising from the presence of the Simpson--Visser black bounce. We analyzed the tidal forces both for a static observer and for a radially infalling observer and showed that differences arise depending on the choice of observer. We used the tidal forces together with the stellar binding forces to determine the Roche radius for neutron stars, white dwarfs, and Sun-like stars, and to investigate how the Simpson--Visser regularization affects the tidal disruption of these astrophysical objects. We also examined whether, for astrophysical black holes such as M87* and Sgr~A*, these stellar disruption processes occur inside or outside the event horizon, and thus whether they are observable.

AI.tldr: This paper examines the Roche radius of various stars near a Simpson--Visser black bounce, comparing tidal forces for static and radially infalling observers, and determining observability of disruptions relative to the event horizon.
AI.motivation: To understand how the Simpson--Visser black bounce's regularization affects tidal disruption events and determine if disruptions occur outside the event horizon for astrophysical black holes like M87* and Sgr A*.
AI.method: Analysis of tidal forces for static and radially infalling observers, calculating Roche radii using tidal and binding forces for neutron stars, white dwarfs, and Sun-like stars.
AI.result: Differences in Roche radii depending on observer perspective were found. For certain astrophysical black holes, disruptions occur outside the event horizon, making them observable.
AI.conclusion: Simpson--Visser regularization impacts tidal disruption dynamics and observability of events outside event horizons, offering insights into black hole physics and stellar interactions.

title: JWST Advanced Deep Extragalactic Survey (JADES) Data Release 5: Wisp Subtraction with the Non-negative Matrix Factorization Algorithm
summary: Wisps are among the most prominent scattered light artifacts in JWST/NIRCam imaging. They often appear in certain regions of the detectors and contaminate observations at surface-brightness levels relevant for faint-source photometry. We introduce a new subtraction method that uses the non-negative matrix factorization (NMF) algorithm to model and remove wisps. Using deep NIRCam observations from the JWST Advanced Deep Extragalactic Survey (JADES) and other programs, we construct multi-component, filter- and detector-specific wisp templates that capture the wisp structures and their exposure-to-exposure morphological variations. Wisps in individual exposures are represented as non-negative linear combinations of these templates, consistent with their additive nature and reducing degeneracies relative to single-template scaling. Compared to existing approaches, our method delivers lower residual root mean square in wisp-affected regions and reduces photometric bias and scatter to levels consistent with clean detector areas. The NMF wisp templates are readily applicable to other datasets and are publicly released to support future NIRCam extragalactic surveys.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a non-negative matrix factorization (NMF) method to model and subtract wisps in JWST/NIRCam images, improving photometric accuracy by using multi-component, detector-specific templates.
AI.motivation: Wisps in NIRCam imaging contaminate faint-source photometry. Existing methods have limitations in handling their morphological variations and reducing residuals.
AI.method: Developed an NMF-based approach to create multi-component wisp templates, which account for filter and detector-specific variations. Each exposure's wisps are modeled as non-negative linear combinations of templates.
AI.result: Achieved lower residual RMS in wisp regions, reduced photometric bias/scatter to levels of clean areas, and demonstrated applicability to other datasets through public template release.
AI.conclusion: The NMF method effectively addresses wisp contamination, enhancing data quality for NIRCam surveys and enabling reliable faint-source studies with publicly available templates.

title: LHC Signatures of Neutral Scalar Cascades in the $Z_3$ symmetric 3HDM
summary: Extending the scalar sector is one of the standard approaches to exploring scenarios beyond the Standard Model. In this work, we examine the collider phenomenology of the Three Higgs Doublet Model (3HDM) in the Type-Z or the democratic Yukawa interaction setup at the LHC. The scalar spectrum of the 3HDM includes three CP-even scalars, two CP-odd scalars, and four charged Higgs bosons. Focusing on cascade decay topologies, we investigate the collider signatures of the neutral scalars through the process $pp \rightarrow SV$, where $S$ is a neutral scalar and $V$ is a vector boson. We perform a cross-section analysis across multiple benchmark points that satisfy both theoretical and experimental constraints, considering two mass hierarchy scenarios: (i) Regular Hierarchy, where the SM-like Higgs is the lightest CP-even scalar, and (ii) Medial Hierarchy, featuring one Higgs boson lighter than the SM Higgs and one heavier. For both scenarios, we study the specific process $pp \rightarrow A \rightarrow HZ \rightarrow b \bar{b} l^+l^-$, performing a cut and count analysis at $\sqrt{s}=14$ TeV. Our results demonstrate that while the Medial Hierarchy scenario allows discovery-level sensitivity for both the CP-even and CP-odd scalars, achieving the same sensitivity in the Regular Hierarchy setup necessitates substantially higher luminosity.

AI.tldr: The paper examines the collider phenomenology of the Three Higgs Doublet Model (3HDM) in the Type-Z or democratic Yukawa interaction setup at the LHC, focusing on cascade decays of neutral scalars in $pp \rightarrow SV$ processes. It analyzes two mass hierarchies, showing Medial Hierarchy allows discovery-level sensitivity for CP-even/odd scalars at current luminosity, while Regular Hierarchy requires higher luminosity.
AI.motivation: The Standard Model's scalar sector extensions like 3HDM provide potential beyond-SM scenarios. Exploring their collider signatures helps in testing theoretical models and probing new physics through LHC data.
AI.method: Cross-section analysis across benchmark points satisfying theoretical/experimental constraints. Studied $pp \rightarrow A \rightarrow HZ \rightarrow b\bar{b}l^+l^-$ process with cut-and-count analysis at 14 TeV. Examined Regular vs. Medial Higgs mass hierarchies.
AI.result: Medial Hierarchy scenario allows discovery potential for both CP-even and CP-odd scalars at current luminosity. Regular Hierarchy needs significantly higher luminosity for comparable sensitivity.
AI.conclusion: Cascade decay channels in 3HDM can constrain mass hierarchies with LHC data. The Medial Hierarchy is more viable for discovery potential at existing luminosity levels, emphasizing the importance of mass ordering in future searches.

title: The initial spin matters: the impact of rapid rotation on magnetic-field amplification at merger
summary: A couple of milliseconds after the merger of a binary system of neutron stars can play a fundamental role in amplifying the comparatively low initial magnetic fields into magnetar strengths. The basic mechanism responsible for this amplification is the Kelvin-Helmholtz instability (KHI) and we here report the first systematic study of the impact of rapid rotation on the KHI-amplification process exploiting general-relativistic magnetohydrodynamic simulations at very high-resolutions of $35\,{\rm m}$. Concentrating on four different spinning configurations, we find that aligned, anti-aligned, and mixed (aligned/anti-aligned) spin configurations lead to markedly different growth rates of the electromagnetic (EM) energy, field topologies, and vortex properties when compared to the irrotational case. These differences arise from intrinsic variations in the system dynamics, such as tidal deformation, collision strength, and contact surface area, with the anti-aligned configuration producing the largest vorticity and growth in EM energy. Importantly, while different spin configurations lead to significantly different initial growth rates of the poloidal/toroidal components, all systems converge to a specific topological partition. Our simulations are confined to a short window in time, but the different EM energies produced as a result of spin will imprint the EM emission at merger and provide information on the spinning state at merger.

AI.tldr: The study shows that rapid rotation in neutron star mergers significantly affects the Kelvin-Helmholtz instability-driven magnetic field amplification, leading to differing electromagnetic energy growth and field topologies across spin configurations.
AI.motivation: To understand how rotation influences the amplification of magnetic fields via the Kelvin-Helmholth instability (KHI) post-neutron star merger, which is crucial for explaining magnetar-strength field generation.
AI.method: High-resolution general-relativistic magnetohydrodynamic simulations (35 m resolution) were conducted across four spinning configurations (aligned, anti-aligned, mixed, irrotational) to analyze KHI effects on EM energy, field topology, and vortex properties.
AI.result: Spin orientation greatly affects EM energy growth rates and field structures. Anti-aligned spin produces the most vorticity and EM energy. All configurations converge to the same topology eventually, but initial evolution differs显著ly.
AI.conclusion: Merger spin states imprint distinct electromagnetic signatures during initial phases, offering observable clues to determine the progenitor system's rotational dynamics at merger.

title: The FarView Low Frequency Radio Array on the Moon's Far Side: Science and Array Architecture
comment: 42 pages, 27 figures, final report for a Phase II NASA Innovative Advanced Concepts (NIAC) design study
summary: FarView is a proposed low frequency radio interferometer for deployment on the lunar far side, enabled by the Moon's radio quiet environment. Operating over 1-50 MHz inaccessible from Earth, FarView will open a new observational window and promote discovery class science in cosmology, heliophysics, Galactic and exoplanet astrophysics. The primary science is measurement of the redshifted 21 cm signal from the Cosmic Dark Ages (z=30-100), identified by the Astro2020 Decadal Survey as a priority cosmology discovery area. FarView will deliver 3D tomographic measurements and precision power spectra of neutral hydrogen in a largely linear regime, enabling tests of inflationary initial conditions, primordial non Gaussianity, dark matter properties, neutrino masses, and early dark energy. The reference design consists of 100000 crossed dipole antennas in a dense core-halo configuration spanning 200 sq km. A compact 4 km core with 83000 dipoles maximizes sensitivity to large scale cosmological modes, while 20000 halo elements extending to 14 km provide angular resolution and calibration for foreground characterization. Sensitivity forecasts indicate a 10-sigma detection of the Dark Ages 21 cm power spectrum at z=30 over five years of half duty cycle lunar night observations. An FFT-based EPIC beamformer is identified as an efficient signal processing architecture. Beyond cosmology, FarView will enable interferometric imaging of low frequency solar radio bursts, advancing space weather studies. Additional capabilities include stellar space weather observations, Galactic cosmic ray tomography via free-free absorption, and searches for auroral radio emission from exoplanet magnetospheres, a probe of exoplanet habitability. FarView represents a flagship class opportunity to establish the Moon as a platform for foundational astrophysics while delivering unique observational capabilities.

AI.tldr: FarView is a proposed lunar far side radio interferometer designed to observe the 1-50 MHz spectrum, focusing on measuring the redshifted 21 cm signal from the Cosmic Dark Ages (z=30-100). It aims to enable discoveries in cosmology through 3D tomography and power spectrum analysis, while also supporting heliophysics, exoplanet studies, and Galactic research with its 100,000-antenna array.
AI.motivation: The Moon's radio-quiet environment allows access to low-frequency radio waves (1-50 MHz) blocked on Earth, creating a new observational window for discovery-class science. The Astro2020 Decadal Survey prioritized studying the Cosmic Dark Ages via 21 cm signals, which requires a lunar-based instrument.
AI.method: A 100,000 crossed-dipole antenna array in a dense core-halo configuration (200 sq km). The 4 km core maximizes cosmological sensitivity, while the 14 km halo provides angular resolution and calibration. An FFT-based EPIC beamformer processes signals, enabling 3D tomographic measurements of neutral hydrogen.
AI.result: Projected to achieve a 10-sigma detection of the Dark Ages 21 cm power spectrum at z=30 over five years. Secondary results include solar radio burst imaging, Galactic cosmic ray studies, and exoplanet magnetosphere detection.
AI.conclusion: FarView represents a flagship mission to establish the Moon as a premier astrophysics platform, enabling transformative cosmological insights and multi-disciplinary astrophysical research through unprecedented low-frequency observations.

title: Excluding Local Hidden Variables in $Λ\barΛ$ Production: The Incompatibility with Angular-Momentum Conservation and CPT Invariance
summary: We analyze spin entanglement in $Λ\barΛ$ pairs produced in the decays of scalar ($h$) and pseudoscalar ($a$) particles, contrasting predictions from quantum field theory (QFT) with those of local hidden-variable theories (LHVTs). Using the self-analyzing weak decays $Λ\to pπ^-$ and $\barΛ \to \bar{p}π^+$, we derive the joint angular distributions within QFT. Our key findings are: For scalar production $h \to Λ\barΛ$, no LHVT respecting locality and angular-momentum conservation can reproduce the QFT distribution. For pseudoscalar production $a \to Λ\barΛ$, a CPT-symmetric LHVT is excluded by positivity constraints given the measured analyzing powers; however, if CPT symmetry is relaxed, an explicit LHVT construction, with uniform hidden-variable measure and response functions satisfying $b_1 c_1 = 3α_Λα_{\barΛ}$, can match the QFT result. These distinct signatures provide clear, experimentally testable criteria to discriminate between QFT and LHVT in $Λ\barΛ$ systems across different production mechanisms.

AI.tldr: The paper examines spin entanglement in $Λ\barΛ$ pairs from scalar ($h$) and pseudoscalar ($a$) decays, showing that while QFT predictions for scalar decay can't be explained by local hidden-variable theories respecting angular-momentum, pseudoscalar decay allows a CPT-violating LHVT with specific constraints.
AI.motivation: To contrast quantum field theory with local hidden-variable theories in explaining spin entanglement phenomena in $Λ\barΛ$ systems produced via different particle decays.
AI.method: Derive joint angular distributions using self-analyzing weak decays ($Λ\to pπ^-$ and $\barΛ \to \bar{p}π^+$) within QFT framework, then test compatibility with LHVT predictions considering locality, angular-momentum conservation, and CPT symmetry.
AI.result: Scalar decay $h \to Λ\barΛ$ cannot be explained by LHVT with locality and angular momentum conservation. Pseudoscalar decay allows a LHVT if CPT symmetry is relaxed (with constraints $b_1 c_1 = 3α_Λα_{\barΛ}$), but CPT-symmetric LHVTs are excluded by positivity.
AI.conclusion: The distinct theoretical signatures from scalar vs pseudoscalar production mechanisms offer clear experimental criteria to test QFT vs LHVT predictions in spin-entangled $Λ\barΛ$ systems.

title: Development of an early warning method incorporating pre-supernova neutrino light curves
summary: Massive stars ($M>8\mathrm{M_\odot}$) emit neutrinos known as pre-supernova (pre-SN) neutrinos through thermal and nuclear interactions for cooling the stellar core during the final stage of stellar evolution. Real-time monitoring of their pre-SN neutrino interaction rate offers a crucial opportunity to issue an early warning to a core-collapse supernova. Some neutrino detectors, including KamLAND and Super-Kamiokande already operate pre-SN alarm systems based on a statistically significant excess of the observed event rate over the expected background. To improve alarm sensitivity, we propose an alarm method which incorporates the time evolution of the observed pre-SN neutrino event rate. The method uses a log likelihood ratio test that references multiple theoretical stellar-evolution models and treats the core collapse time as a nuisance parameter to be profiled over. The performance of the proposed method was evaluated using simulated data for the KamLAND, Super-Kamiokande with dissolved Gadolinium (SK-Gd) and their combined analysis. The results demonstrate a significant improvement in the warning time compared to the conventional rate-only method, while maintaining the same false alarm rate.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes an improved method for pre-SN neutrino detection using time-evolving event rates and log likelihood ratios, enhancing warning times without increasing false alarms.
AI.motivation: To improve early warning systems for core-collapse supernovae by enhancing the sensitivity of existing neutrino detectors like KamLAND and SK-Gd.
AI.method: Uses a log likelihood ratio test incorporating multiple stellar models and profiles core collapse time as a nuisance parameter to analyze time-evolving event rates.
AI.result: Simulations show significant improvement in warning time compared to traditional methods, maintaining the same false alarm rate.
AI.conclusion: The proposed method provides earlier supernova warnings, benefiting astrophysical observations and experiments dependent on timely detection.

title: Unveiling a Universal Formalism for Quantum Entanglement in Arbitrary Spin Decays
summary: We present a comprehensive theoretical framework for probing quantum entanglement in the decay angular distributions of a spin-$S$ particle-antiparticle pair $A\bar{A}$, where each particle decays sequentially into a two-body final state, $A\to B+C$ and $\bar{A}\to\bar{B}+\bar{C}$, with $B(\bar{B})$ carrying spin $b$ and $C(\bar{C})$ being spinless. Starting from the most general polarized initial state, we derive the fully differential angular distribution $\mathcal{W}(θ_1,θ_2,φ_1,φ_2)$ and identify observables $\langle\cos(2S(φ_1\mpφ_2))\rangle$ whose expectation values directly depend on the entanglement-sensitive coefficients $\text{Re}\left(α_{-S,\mp S}α_{S,\pm S}^*\right)$ of the initial state. The proportionality factor $\mathcal{C}(S,b)$ in these relations is computed explicitly. For bosonic decays ($b=0,1,2,\ldots$), $\mathcal{C}(S,b)$ is universal and independent of decay dynamics; in particular, $\mathcal{C}(S,0)=1/2$ for any $S$, and $\mathcal{C}(1,1)=1/8$, matching known results for $W^+W^-$ decays. For fermionic decays ($b=\frac{1}{2},\frac{3}{2},\frac{5}{2}\ldots$), $\mathcal{C}(S,b)$ depends explicitly on the spin analysis powers $α_{A/\bar{A}}$, making entanglement extraction more decay-dependent. We further demonstrate, within the context of $e^+e^-\toγ^*\to A\bar{A}$ production, how $α_{A/\bar{A}}$ can be determined experimentally using specific angular observables restricted to the beam-axis region. Our results highlight the special role of bosonic decays in providing clean, model-independent tests of quantum entanglement at colliders, while outlining a pathway for entanglement measurement in fermionic cases through supplementary polarization information.

AI.tldr: The paper presents a theoretical framework to probe quantum entanglement in the decay angular distributions of spin-$S$ particle-antiparticle pairs. It derives observables that depend directly on entanglement-sensitive coefficients in the initial state, showing differences between bosonic and fermionic decays in terms of dynamics independence and experimental determination of spin analysis powers.
AI.motivation: To develop a method for measuring quantum entanglement in particle physics experiments by analyzing angular distributions of decay products. This addresses the need for model-independent tests of entanglement, especially highlighting bosonic decays as cleaner systems and offering pathways for fermionic decays.
AI.method: Starting from a general polarized initial state, the authors derive the fully differential angular distribution, identify entanglement-sensitive observables involving angular correlations ⟨cos(2S(φ₁∓φ₂))⟩, compute proportionality factors C(S,b) for bosons and fermions, and outline experimental determination of spin analysis powers using beam-axis angular observables in e⁺e⁻ collisions.
AI.result: For bosonic decays (b integer), C(S,b) is universal: e.g., C(S,0)=1/2 and C(1,1)=1/8. For fermionic decays (b half-integer), C(S,b) depends on decay dynamics via α_{A/Ā}. Experimental procedures for determining α parameters via beam-axis observables are demonstrated, enabling entanglement extraction in fermionic cases.
AI.conclusion: Bosonic decays provide model-independent entanglement tests due to their universal coefficients, making them ideal for collider experiments. Fermionic decays require additional polarization data but still offer viable pathways. The framework advances entanglement measurement techniques in high-energy physics.

title: GRB~250704B/EP250704a a Short Gamma-Ray Burst Powered by a Magnetar
summary: GRB~250704B/EP250704a, identified as a short gamma-ray burst (sGRB), exhibited prolonged X-ray emission following the prompt phase and, in optical and infrared (IR) bands, an unusual one-day plateau succeeded by a rapid decline. This sGRB was observed by multiple satellites and ground-based observatories across the electromagnetic spectrum. This study presents temporal and spectral analyses from radio to gamma-ray frequencies, spanning several observation periods beginning after the trigger and continuing for nearly 2 days. The results of the temporal and spectral analyses of the prompt episode, the extended X-ray component, and the afterglow phase are consistent with a millisecond magnetar undergoing accretion. The long-lasting X-ray emission is attributed to the internal energy dissipation of the magnetar spin-down power, governed by the magnetization parameter; the extended optical/IR plateau to synchrotron afterglow emission with energy injection; and the steep decay to changes in microphysical parameters during the post-jet break phase. The X-ray observations are consistent with the superposition of spin-down luminosity and synchrotron afterglow scenario. These findings suggest that the compact-object remnant is most likely a long-lived magnetar.

AI.tldr: The analysis of sGRB 250704B/EP250704a reveals prolonged X-ray and optical/IR emissions consistent with a millisecond magnetar's spin-down and accretion processes. The observations support the remnant being a long-lived magnetar.
AI.motivation: To understand the origin of unusual prolonged emissions in sGRBs and test the magnetar model by analyzing multi-wavelength data.
AI.method: Temporal and spectral analyses of multi-messenger observations (radio to gamma-rays) spanning 2 days post-burst. Components studied include the prompt phase, extended X-ray emission, and optical/IR afterglow.
AI.result: X-ray emission linked to magnetar spin-down energy, optical/IR plateau due to synchrotron with energy injection, and late decay explained by microphysical changes post-jet break. X-ray data align with magnetar spin-down plus synchrotron emission.
AI.conclusion: The observed features strongly indicate that the sGRB remnant is a long-lived millisecond magnetar rather than a short-lived black hole.

title: Gravitational Wave Signature of Aspherical Bubbles Driven by Thermal Fluctuation
summary: Cosmological first-order phase transitions are a well-motivated source of stochastic gravitational waves (GWs), but most predictions are made based on the highly idealized model of perfectly spherical vacuum bubbles, neglecting thermal fluctuations. In this work we use $(3+1)$-dimensional lattice simulations of a scalar model with thermal initial conditions to quantify how thermal fluctuations distort bubble profiles and modify the resulting GW spectrum. We find that thermal fluctuations can strongly break spherical symmetry at early times, allowing even an isolated bubble to emit GWs. In multi-bubble simulations, thermal fluctuations systematically reshape the spectrum, suppressing the infrared part while enhancing and broadening the high-$k$ tail. We further provide an analytical estimate for the ultraviolet regime of the GW spectrum, which is in good agreement with our lattice results and suggests that this regime is dominated by thermal fluctuations. These effects could leave observable imprints in future GW searches.

AI.tldr: Thermal fluctuations significantly impact gravitational wave spectra from cosmological phase transitions, altering both low and high-frequency components.
AI.motivation: To address the limitations of idealized spherical bubble models by incorporating thermal fluctuations using lattice simulations.
AI.method: 3+1 dimensional lattice simulations of a scalar model with thermal initial conditions to study bubble dynamics and gravitational wave emission.
AI.result: Thermal fluctuations break spherical symmetry, cause IR suppression and UV enhancement in GW spectra, with analytical UV estimates matching simulation results.
AI.conclusion: Thermal fluctuations play a critical role in shaping GW signals, offering observable signatures for future gravitational wave searches.

title: Two-loop rainbow neutrino masses in a non-invertible symmetry
summary: We propose two-loop rainbow type of the neutrino mass model via ${Z}_2$ gauging of ${Z}_6$ non-invertible symmetry in which we introduce three families of isospin doublet vector-like fermions, heavy right-handed neutrinos and isospin doublet and singlet bosons. All new fields, which have nonzero charges under the non-invertible symmetry, can be dark matter candidates, since the non-invertible symmetry possesses a remnant ${Z}_2$ symmetry that plays a role in assuring the stability of our dark matter candidate. Even though the non-invertible symmetry is dynamically broken at one-loop level, its violation does not affect our scenario. In this paper, we especially consider the lightest mode of the neutral components in the doublet vector-like fermions as our main dark matter candidate. The dark matter is potentially degenerated to the other two families of neutral fermions, since the mass difference is induced at one-loop level. Thus, we consider our dark matter candidate in rather simpler co-annihilation system among their particles. Considering all the constraints of neutrino oscillation data, lepton flavor violations, muon $g-2$ and the relic density of dark matter, we perform the numerical analysis and show some allowed regions for these phenomenology. Due to our dark matter nature, the sum of neutrino masses in case of normal hierarchy is larger than that in case of inverted hierarchy, which is opposite situation compared with typical active neutrino models.

AI.tldr: This paper proposes a two-loop rainbow-type neutrino mass model using a Z2 gauging of Z6 non-invertible symmetry, introducing vector-like fermions, right-handed neutrinos, and bosons as dark matter candidates. The model addresses neutrino oscillation data, muon g-2, and dark matter relic density, showing unique predictions for the sum of neutrino masses in hierarchy cases.
AI.motivation: To explore a new mechanism for generating neutrino masses and dark matter stability using non-invertible symmetries while addressing experimental constraints like neutrino oscillations, lepton flavor violation, and muon g-2 anomalies.
AI.method: Constructs a Z2 gauged Z6 non-invertible symmetry model with three vector-like fermion families, right-handed neutrinos, and scalar bosons. Analyzes the dark matter candidate stability, co-annihilation processes, and confronts the model with observational data including cosmological and particle physics constraints.
AI.result: Shows that the lightest neutral fermion serves as a viable dark matter candidate with allowed parameter regions. Reveals that the neutrino mass sum in normal hierarchy exceeds inverted hierarchy cases, opposite to standard models.
